docblock.description: Setup() - this method will get the current user agent and store it in the session as 'valid data'
Validate() - this method will determine if the current user agent matches the user agent we stored when we initialized this variable.
SetValidData() - This method should be used to store the environment variables that will be needed in order to validate the session later in the validate() method.
docblock.long-description: These values are stored in the session in the __ZF namespace, in an array named VALID

docblock.description: GetValidData() - This method should be used to retrieve the environment variables that will be needed to 'validate' a session.

Namespace - which namespace this instance of zend-session is saving-to/getting-from
Single instance namespace array to ensure data security.
Whether or not session permits writing (modification of $_SESSION[])
Whether or not session permits reading (reading data in $_SESSION[])
Since expiring data is handled at startup to avoid __destruct difficulties, the data that will be expiring at end of this request is held here
__construct() - Returns an instance object bound to a particular, isolated section of the session, identified by $namespace name (defaulting to 'Default').
docblock.long-description: The optional argument $singleInstance will prevent construction of additional instance objects acting as accessors to this $namespace.

tag.name: param

docblock.description: lock() - mark a session/namespace as readonly
unlock() - unmark a session/namespace to enable read & write
unlockAll() - unmark all session/namespaces to enable read & write
isLocked() - return lock status, true if, and only if, read-only
unsetAll() - unset all variables in this namespace
__get() - method to get a variable in this object's current namespace

tag.name: param
tag.description: • programmatic name of a key, in a pair in the current namespace

tag.name: param

docblock.description: apply() - enables applying user-selected function, such as array_merge() to the namespace Parameters following the $callback argument are passed to the callback function.
applySet() - enables applying user-selected function, and sets entire namespace to the result Result of $callback must be an array.
docblock.long-description:
Parameters following the $callback argument are passed to the callback function. Caveat: ignores members expiring now.
Example: $namespace->applySet('array_merge', array('tree' => 'apple', 'fruit' => 'peach'), array('flower' => 'rose'));

docblock.description: __isset() - determine if a variable in this object's namespace is set

tag.name: param
tag.description: • programmatic name of a key, in a pair in the current namespace

docblock.description: __unset() - unset a variable in this object's namespace.

tag.name: param
tag.description: • programmatic name of a key, in a pair in the current namespace

docblock.description: setExpirationSeconds() - expire the namespace, or specific variables after a specified number of seconds

tag.name: param
tag.description: • OPTIONAL list of variables to expire (defaults to all)

docblock.description: setExpirationHops() - expire the namespace, or specific variables after a specified number of page hops

tag.name: param
tag.description: • how many "hops" (number of subsequent requests) before expiring

tag.name: param
tag.description: • OPTIONAL list of variables to expire (defaults to all)

tag.name: param
tag.description: • OPTIONAL if set, only count a hop/request if this namespace is used

namespaceUnset() - unset a namespace or a variable within a namespace
namespaceGet() - Get $name variable from $namespace, returning by reference.
namespaceGetAll() - Get an array containing $namespace, including expiring data.

docblock.description: Session table primary key value assignment
Session table last modification time column
Whether or not the lifetime of an existing session should be overridden

docblock.long-description:
$config is an instance of Zend_Config or an array of key/value pairs containing configuration options for Zend_Session_SaveHandler_DbTable and Zend_Db_Table_Abstract. These are the configuration options for Zend_Session_SaveHandler_DbTable:
primaryAssignment => (string|array) Session table primary key value assignment (optional; default: 1 => sessionId) You have to assign a value to each primary key of your session table. The value of this configuration option is either a string if you have only one primary key or an array if you have multiple primary keys. The array consists of numeric keys starting at 1 and string values. There are some values which will be replaced by session information:
sessionId => The id of the current session sessionName => The name of the current session sessionSavePath => The save path of the current session
NOTE: One of your assignments MUST contain 'sessionId' as value!
modifiedColumn => (string) Session table last modification time column
lifetimeColumn => (string) Session table lifetime column
dataColumn => (string) Session table data column
lifetime => (integer) Session lifetime (optional; default: ini_get('session.gc_maxlifetime'))
overrideLifetime => (boolean) Whether or not the lifetime of an existing session should be overridden (optional; default: false)

docblock.description: Set session lifetime and optional whether or not the lifetime of an existing session should be overridden
docblock.long-description: $lifetime === false resets lifetime to session.gc_maxlifetime

docblock.description: Set whether or not the lifetime of an existing session should be overridden
Retrieve whether or not the lifetime of an existing session should be overridden
Calls other protected methods for individual setup tasks and requirement checks
Initialize session table primary key value assignment
Check for required session table columns
Retrieve session table primary key values

docblock.description: Static methods for loading classes and files.
Loads a class from a PHP file. The filename must be formatted as "$class.php".
docblock.long-description:
If $dirs is a string or an array, it will search the directories in the order supplied, and attempt to load the first matching file.
If $dirs is null, it will split the class name at underscores to generate a path hierarchy (e.g., "Zend_Example_Class" will map to "Zend/Example/Class.php").
If the file was not found in the $dirs, or if no $dirs were specified, it will attempt to load it from PHP's include_path.

tag.name: param
tag.description: • The full class name of a Zend component.

tag.name: param
tag.description: • OPTIONAL Either a path or an array of paths to search.

docblock.description: Loads a PHP file. This is a wrapper for PHP's include() function.
docblock.long-description:
$filename must be the complete filename, including any extension such as ".php". Note that a security check is performed that does not permit extended characters in the filename. This method is intended for loading Zend Framework files.
If $dirs is a string or an array, it will search the directories in the order supplied, and attempt to load the first matching file.
If the file was not found in the $dirs, or if no $dirs were specified, it will attempt to load it from PHP's include_path.
If $once is TRUE, it will use include_once() instead of include().

tag.name: param
tag.description: • OPTIONAL either a path or array of paths to search.

docblock.description: Returns TRUE if the $filename is readable, or FALSE otherwise.
docblock.long-description:
This function uses the PHP include_path, where PHP's is_readable() does not.
Note from ZF-2900: If you use custom error handler, please check whether return value from error_reporting() is zero or not. At mark of fopen() can not suppress warning if the handler is used.

docblock.description: Explode an include path into an array
docblock.long-description: If no path provided, uses current include_path. Works around issues that occur when the path includes stream schemas.

docblock.description: spl_autoload() suitable implementation for supporting class autoloading.
docblock.long-description: Attach to spl_autoload() using the following: spl_autoload_register(array('Zend_Loader', 'autoload'));

tag.name: return
tag.description: Class name on success; false on failure

tag.name: throws
tag.description: if spl_autoload() is not found or if the specified class does not have an autoload() method.

docblock.description: Ensure that filename does not contain exploits

docblock.long-description:
include() is not prefixed with the @ operator because if the file is loaded and contains a parse error, execution will halt silently and this is difficult to debug.
Always set display_errors = Off on production servers!

Convert the supplied filename into the namespace-aware standard, based on the Framework Interop Group reference implementation: http://groups.google.com/group/php-standards/web/psr-0-final-proposal
The filename must be formatted as "$file.php".

docblock.description: Generates the standard date object, could be a unix timestamp, localized date, string, integer, array and so on. Also parts of dates or time are supported Always set the default timezone: http://php.net/date_default_timezone_set For example, in your bootstrap: date_default_timezone_set('America/Los_Angeles'); For detailed instructions please look in the docu.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Date value or value of date part to set ,depending on $part. If null the actual time is set

docblock.description: Sets class wide options, if no option was given, the actual set options will be returned

tag.name: return
tag.description: array if no option was given

docblock.description: Returns this object's internal UNIX timestamp (equivalent to Zend_Date::TIMESTAMP).
docblock.long-description: If the timestamp is too large for integers, then the return value will be a string. This function does not return the timestamp as an object. Use clone() or copyPart() instead.

docblock.description: Returns the calculated timestamp HINT: timestamps are always GMT

tag.name: param
tag.description: Timestamp to calculate, when null the actual timestamp is calculated

docblock.description: Compares two timestamps, returning the difference as integer

Returns a string representation of the object Supported format tokens are: G - era, y - year, Y - ISO year, M - month, w - week of year, D - day of year, d - day of month E - day of week, e - number of weekday (1-7), h - hour 1-12, H - hour 0-23, m - minute, s - second A - milliseconds of day, z - timezone, Z - timezone offset, S - fractional second, a - period of day
docblock.long-description:
Additionally format tokens but non ISO conform are: SS - day suffix, eee - php number of weekday(0-6), ddd - number of days per month l - Leap year, B - swatch internet time, I - daylight saving time, X - timezone offset in seconds r - RFC2822 format, U - unix timestamp
Not supported ISO tokens are u - extended year, Q - quarter, q - quarter, L - stand alone month, W - week of month F - day of week of month, g - modified julian, c - stand alone weekday, k - hour 0-11, K - hour 1-24 v - wall zone

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Rule for formatting output. If null the default date format is used

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Type for the format string which overrides the standard setting

docblock.description: Returns a string representation of the date which is equal with the timestamp
Returns a integer representation of the object But returns false when the given part is no value f.e. Month-Name

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Defines the date or datepart to return as integer

docblock.description: Returns an array representation of the object

Returns a representation of a date or datepart This could be for example a localized monthname, the time without date, the era or only the fractional seconds. There are about 50 different supported date parts.
docblock.long-description: For a complete list of supported datepart values look into the docu

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to return, if null the timestamp is returned

docblock.description: Private function to make a comment of a token
Return digit from standard names (english) Faster implementation than locale aware searching
Counts the exact year number < 70 - 2000 added, >70 < 100 - 1900, others just returned

Sets the given date as new date or a given datepart as new datepart returning the new datepart This could be for example a localized dayname, the date without time, the month or only the seconds. There are about 50 different supported date parts.
docblock.long-description: For a complete list of supported datepart values look into the docu

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to set, if null the timestamp is set

docblock.description: Adds a date or datepart to the existing date, by extracting $part from $date, and modifying this object by adding that part. The $part is then extracted from this object and returned as an integer or numeric string (for large values, or $part's corresponding to pre-defined formatted date strings).
docblock.long-description: This could be for example a ISO 8601 date, the hour the monthname or only the minute. There are about 50 different supported date parts. For a complete list of supported datepart values look into the docu.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to add, if null the timestamp is added

docblock.description: Subtracts a date from another date.
docblock.long-description: This could be for example a RFC2822 date, the time, the year or only the timestamp. There are about 50 different supported date parts. For a complete list of supported datepart values look into the docu Be aware: Adding -2 Months is not equal to Subtracting 2 Months !!!

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to sub, if null the timestamp is subtracted

docblock.description: Compares a date or datepart with the existing one.
docblock.long-description: Returns -1 if earlier, 0 if equal and 1 if later.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Date or datepart to compare with the date object

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to compare, if null the timestamp is subtracted

docblock.description: Returns a new instance of Zend_Date with the selected part copied.
docblock.long-description: To make an exact copy, use PHP's clone keyword. For a complete list of supported date part values look into the docu. If a date part is copied, all other date parts are set to standard values. For example: If only YEAR is copied, the returned date object is equal to 01-01-YEAR 00:00:00 (01-01-1970 00:00:00 is equal to timestamp 0) If only HOUR is copied, the returned date object is equal to 01-01-1970 HOUR:00:00 (so $this contains a timestamp equal to a timestamp of 0 plus HOUR).

tag.name: param
tag.description: Part of the date to compare, if null the timestamp is subtracted

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL New object's locale. No adjustments to timezone are made.

docblock.description: Internal function, returns the offset of a given timezone

tag.name: param
tag.description: Use dst correction if option is set

tag.name: return
tag.description: new timestamp or Zend_Date depending on calculation

tag.name: param
tag.description: Part of the date to calculate, if null the timestamp is used

docblock.description: Returns true when both date objects or date parts are equal.
docblock.long-description: For example: 15.May.2000 <-> 15.June.2000 Equals only for Day or Year... all other will return false

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to compare, if null the timestamp is used

docblock.description: Returns if the given date or datepart is earlier For example: 15.May.2000 <-> 13.June.1999 will return true for day, year and date, but not for month

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to compare, if null the timestamp is used

docblock.description: Returns if the given date or datepart is later For example: 15.May.2000 <-> 13.June.1999 will return true for month but false for day, year and date Returns if the given date is later

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Part of the date to compare, if null the timestamp is used

docblock.description: Returns only the time of the date as new Zend_Date object For example: 15.May.2000 10:11:23 will return a dateobject equal to 01.Jan.1970 10:11:23

tag.name: param
tag.description: Time to calculate with, if null the actual time is taken

docblock.description: Sets a new time for the date object. Format defines how to parse the time string.
docblock.long-description: Also a complete date can be given, but only the time is used for setting. For example: dd.MMMM.yyTHH:mm' and 'ss sec'-> 10.May.07T25:11 and 44 sec => 1h11min44sec + 1 day Returned is the new date object and the existing date is left as it was before

docblock.description: Adds a time to the existing date. Format defines how to parse the time string.
docblock.long-description: If only parts are given the other parts are set to 0. If no format is given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: HH:mm:ss -> 10 -> +10 hours

docblock.description: Subtracts a time from the existing date. Format defines how to parse the time string.
docblock.long-description: If only parts are given the other parts are set to 0. If no format is given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: HH:mm:ss -> 10 -> -10 hours

docblock.description: Compares the time from the existing date. Format defines how to parse the time string.
docblock.long-description: If only parts are given the other parts are set to default. If no format us given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: HH:mm:ss -> 10 -> 10 hours

docblock.description: Returns a clone of $this, with the time part set to 00:00:00.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Date to calculate with, if null the actual date is taken

docblock.description: Sets a new date for the date object. Format defines how to parse the date string.
docblock.long-description: Also a complete date with time can be given, but only the date is used for setting. For example: MMMM.yy HH:mm-> May.07 22:11 => 01.May.07 00:00 Returned is the new date object and the existing time is left as it was before

docblock.description: Adds a date to the existing date object. Format defines how to parse the date string.
docblock.long-description: If only parts are given the other parts are set to 0. If no format is given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: MM.dd.YYYY -> 10 -> +10 months

docblock.description: Subtracts a date from the existing date object. Format defines how to parse the date string.
docblock.long-description: If only parts are given the other parts are set to 0. If no format is given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: MM.dd.YYYY -> 10 -> -10 months Be aware: Subtracting 2 months is not equal to Adding -2 months !!!

docblock.description: Compares the date from the existing date object, ignoring the time.
docblock.long-description: Format defines how to parse the date string. If only parts are given the other parts are set to 0. If no format is given, the standardformat of this locale is used. For example: 10.01.2000 => 10.02.1999 -> false

docblock.description: Returns the full ISO 8601 date from the date object.
docblock.long-description: Always the complete ISO 8601 specifiction is used. If an other ISO date is needed (ISO 8601 defines several formats) use toString() instead. This function does not return the ISO date as object. Use copy() instead.

docblock.description: Sets a new date for the date object. Not given parts are set to default.
docblock.long-description: Only supported ISO 8601 formats are accepted. For example: 050901 -> 01.Sept.2005 00:00:00, 20050201T10:00:30 -> 01.Feb.2005 10h00m30s Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Adds a ISO date to the date object. Not given parts are set to default.
docblock.long-description: Only supported ISO 8601 formats are accepted. For example: 050901 -> + 01.Sept.2005 00:00:00, 10:00:00 -> +10h Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Subtracts a ISO date from the date object. Not given parts are set to default.
docblock.long-description: Only supported ISO 8601 formats are accepted. For example: 050901 -> - 01.Sept.2005 00:00:00, 10:00:00 -> -10h Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Compares a ISO date with the date object. Not given parts are set to default.
docblock.long-description: Only supported ISO 8601 formats are accepted. For example: 050901 -> - 01.Sept.2005 00:00:00, 10:00:00 -> -10h Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns a RFC 822 compilant datestring from the date object.
docblock.long-description: This function does not return the RFC date as object. Use copy() instead.

docblock.description: Sets a RFC 822 date as new date for the date object.
docblock.long-description: Only RFC 822 compilant date strings are accepted. For example: Sat, 14 Feb 09 00:31:30 +0100 Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Adds a RFC 822 date to the date object.
docblock.long-description: ARPA messages are used in emails or HTTP Headers. Only RFC 822 compilant date strings are accepted. For example: Sat, 14 Feb 09 00:31:30 +0100 Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Subtracts a RFC 822 date from the date object.
docblock.long-description: ARPA messages are used in emails or HTTP Headers. Only RFC 822 compilant date strings are accepted. For example: Sat, 14 Feb 09 00:31:30 +0100 Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Compares a RFC 822 compilant date with the date object.
docblock.long-description: ARPA messages are used in emails or HTTP Headers. Only RFC 822 compilant date strings are accepted. For example: Sat, 14 Feb 09 00:31:30 +0100 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the time of sunrise for this date and a given location as new date object For a list of cities and correct locations use the class Zend_Date_Cities

tag.name: param
tag.description: location of sunrise ['horizon'] -> civil, nautic, astronomical, effective (default) ['longitude'] -> longitude of location ['latitude'] -> latitude of location

docblock.description: Returns the time of sunset for this date and a given location as new date object For a list of cities and correct locations use the class Zend_Date_Cities

tag.name: param
tag.description: location of sunset ['horizon'] -> civil, nautic, astronomical, effective (default) ['longitude'] -> longitude of location ['latitude'] -> latitude of location

docblock.description: Returns an array with the sunset and sunrise dates for all horizon types For a list of cities and correct locations use the class Zend_Date_Cities

tag.name: param
tag.description: location of suninfo ['horizon'] -> civil, nautic, astronomical, effective (default) ['longitude'] -> longitude of location ['latitude'] -> latitude of location

docblock.description: Check a given year for leap year.
Returns true, if the year is a leap year.
Returns if the set date is todays date
Returns if the set date is yesterdays date
Returns if the set date is tomorrows date
Returns the actual date as new date object
Internal calculation, returns the requested date type

tag.name: param
tag.description: Datevalue to calculate with, if null the actual value is taken

docblock.description: Returns only the year from the date object as new object.

Sets a new year If the year is between 0 and 69, 2000 will be set (2000-2069) If the year if between 70 and 99, 1999 will be set (1970-1999) 3 or 4 digit years are set as expected. If you need to set year 0-99 use set() instead.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Adds the year to the existing date object If the year is between 0 and 69, 2000 will be added (2000-2069) If the year if between 70 and 99, 1999 will be added (1970-1999) 3 or 4 digit years are added as expected. If you need to add years from 0-99 use add() instead.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Subs the year from the existing date object If the year is between 0 and 69, 2000 will be subtracted (2000-2069) If the year if between 70 and 99, 1999 will be subtracted (1970-1999) 3 or 4 digit years are subtracted as expected. If you need to subtract years from 0-99 use sub() instead.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Compares the year with the existing date object, ignoring other date parts.
docblock.long-description: For example: 10.03.2000 -> 15.02.2000 -> true Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns only the month from the date object as new object.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Month to calculate with, if null the actual month is taken

docblock.description: Sets a new month The month can be a number or a string. Setting months lower then 0 and greater then 12 will result in adding or subtracting the relevant year. (12 months equal one year) If a localized monthname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Adds months to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The month can be a number or a string. Adding months lower then 0 and greater then 12 will result in adding or subtracting the relevant year. (12 months equal one year) If a localized monthname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale. Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Subtracts months from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The month can be a number or a string. Subtracting months lower then 0 and greater then 12 will result in adding or subtracting the relevant year. (12 months equal one year) If a localized monthname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale. Returned is the new date object

docblock.description: Compares the month with the existing date object, ignoring other date parts.
docblock.long-description: For example: 10.03.2000 -> 15.03.1950 -> true Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the day as new date object Example: 20.May.1986 -> 20.Jan.1970 00:00:00

tag.name: param
tag.description: Day to calculate, when null the actual day is calculated

docblock.description: Sets a new day The day can be a number or a string. Setting days lower then 0 or greater than the number of this months days will result in adding or subtracting the relevant month.
docblock.long-description: If a localized dayname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale. Returned is the new date object Example: setDay('Montag', 'de_AT'); will set the monday of this week as day.

docblock.description: Adds days to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The day can be a number or a string. Adding days lower then 0 or greater than the number of this months days will result in adding or subtracting the relevant month. If a localized dayname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale.

docblock.description: Subtracts days from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The day can be a number or a string. Subtracting days lower then 0 or greater than the number of this months days will result in adding or subtracting the relevant month. If a localized dayname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale.

docblock.description: Compares the day with the existing date object, ignoring other date parts.
docblock.long-description: For example: 'Monday', 'en' -> 08.Jan.2007 -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the weekday as new date object Weekday is always from 1-7 Example: 09-Jan-2007 -> 2 = Tuesday -> 02-Jan-1970 (when 02.01.1970 is also Tuesday)

tag.name: param
tag.description: Weekday to calculate, when null the actual weekday is calculated

docblock.description: Sets a new weekday The weekday can be a number or a string. If a localized weekday name is given, then it will be parsed as a date in $locale (defaults to the same locale as $this).
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object. Example: setWeekday(3); will set the wednesday of this week as day.

docblock.description: Adds weekdays to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The weekday can be a number or a string. If a localized dayname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale. Returned is the new date object Example: addWeekday(3); will add the difference of days from the begining of the month until wednesday.

docblock.description: Subtracts weekdays from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The weekday can be a number or a string. If a localized dayname is given it will be parsed with the default locale or the optional set locale. Returned is the new date object Example: subWeekday(3); will subtract the difference of days from the begining of the month until wednesday.

docblock.description: Compares the weekday with the existing date object, ignoring other date parts.
docblock.long-description: For example: 'Monday', 'en' -> 08.Jan.2007 -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the day of year as new date object Example: 02.Feb.1986 10:00:00 -> 02.Feb.1970 00:00:00
Sets a new day of year The day of year is always a number.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.2004 -> setDayOfYear(10) -> 10.Jan.2004

docblock.description: Adds a day of year to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The day of year is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: addDayOfYear(10); will add 10 days to the existing date object.

docblock.description: Subtracts a day of year from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The day of year is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: subDayOfYear(10); will subtract 10 days from the existing date object.

docblock.description: Compares the day of year with the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: For example: compareDayOfYear(33) -> 02.Feb.2007 -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the hour as new date object Example: 02.Feb.1986 10:30:25 -> 01.Jan.1970 10:00:00
Sets a new hour The hour is always a number.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> setHour(7); -> 04.May.1993 07:07:25

docblock.description: Adds hours to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The hour is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> addHour(12); -> 05.May.1993 01:07:25

docblock.description: Subtracts hours from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The hour is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> subHour(6); -> 05.May.1993 07:07:25

docblock.description: Compares the hour with the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: For example: 10:30:25 -> compareHour(10) -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the minute as new date object Example: 02.Feb.1986 10:30:25 -> 01.Jan.1970 00:30:00
Sets a new minute The minute is always a number.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> setMinute(29); -> 04.May.1993 13:29:25

docblock.description: Adds minutes to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The minute is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> addMinute(65); -> 04.May.1993 13:12:25

docblock.description: Subtracts minutes from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The minute is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> subMinute(9); -> 04.May.1993 12:58:25

docblock.description: Compares the minute with the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: For example: 10:30:25 -> compareMinute(30) -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the second as new date object Example: 02.Feb.1986 10:30:25 -> 01.Jan.1970 00:00:25
Sets new seconds to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The second is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> setSecond(100); -> 04.May.1993 13:08:40

docblock.description: Adds seconds to the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The second is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> addSecond(65); -> 04.May.1993 13:08:30

docblock.description: Subtracts seconds from the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: The second is always a number. Returned is the new date object Example: 04.May.1993 13:07:25 -> subSecond(10); -> 04.May.1993 13:07:15

docblock.description: Compares the second with the existing date object.
docblock.long-description: For example: 10:30:25 -> compareSecond(25) -> 0 Returns if equal, earlier or later

docblock.description: Returns the precision for fractional seconds
Sets a new precision for fractional seconds
Returns the milliseconds of the date object
Sets new milliseconds for the date object Example: setMilliSecond(550, 2) -> equals +5 Sec +50 MilliSec

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Millisecond to set, when null the actual millisecond is set

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Fraction precision of the given milliseconds

docblock.description: Adds milliseconds to the date object

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Millisecond to add, when null the actual millisecond is added

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Fractional precision for the given milliseconds

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Millisecond to sub, when null the actual millisecond is subtracted

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Fractional precision for the given milliseconds

docblock.description: Compares only the millisecond part, returning the difference

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Millisecond to compare, when null the actual millisecond is compared

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Fractional precision for the given milliseconds

docblock.description: Returns the week as new date object using monday as begining of the week Example: 12.Jan.2007 -> 08.Jan.1970 00:00:00
Sets a new week. The week is always a number. The day of week is not changed.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 09.Jan.2007 13:07:25 -> setWeek(1); -> 02.Jan.2007 13:07:25

docblock.description: Adds a week. The week is always a number. The day of week is not changed.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 09.Jan.2007 13:07:25 -> addWeek(1); -> 16.Jan.2007 13:07:25

docblock.description: Subtracts a week. The week is always a number. The day of week is not changed.
docblock.long-description: Returned is the new date object Example: 09.Jan.2007 13:07:25 -> subWeek(1); -> 02.Jan.2007 13:07:25

docblock.description: Compares only the week part, returning the difference Returned is the new date object Returns if equal, earlier or later Example: 09.Jan.2007 13:07:25 -> compareWeek(2); -> 0
Sets a new standard locale for the date object.
docblock.long-description: This locale will be used for all functions Returned is the really set locale. Example: 'de_XX' will be set to 'de' because 'de_XX' does not exist 'xx_YY' will be set to 'root' because 'xx' does not exist

tag.name: throws
tag.description: When the given locale does not exist

docblock.description: Checks if the given date is a real date or datepart.
docblock.long-description: Returns false if a expected datepart is missing or a datepart exceeds its possible border. But the check will only be done for the expected dateparts which are given by format. If no format is given the standard dateformat for the actual locale is used. f.e. 30.February.2007 will return false if format is 'dd.MMMM.YYYY'

tag.name: param
tag.description: (Optional) Format for parsing the date string

tag.name: return
tag.description: True when all date parts are correct

docblock.description: Returns the ISO Token for all localized constants
Set this object to have a new UNIX timestamp.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL timestamp; defaults to local time using time()

docblock.description: Returns this object's UNIX timestamp A timestamp greater then the integer range will be returned as string This function does not return the timestamp as object. Use copy() instead.

docblock.long-description: Returns time(). This method exists to allow unit tests to work-around methods that might otherwise be hard-coded to use time(). For example, this makes it possible to test isYesterday() in Date.php.

docblock.description: Internal mktime function used by Zend_Date.
docblock.long-description:
The timestamp returned by mktime() can exceed the precision of traditional UNIX timestamps, by allowing PHP to auto-convert to using a float value.
Returns a timestamp relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC. DST (Summer/Winter) is depriciated since php 5.1.0. Year has to be 4 digits otherwise it would be recognised as year 70 AD instead of 1970 AD as expected !!

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL true = other arguments are for UTC time, false = arguments are for local time/date

tag.name: return
tag.description: timestamp (number of seconds elapsed relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC)

docblock.description: Returns true, if given $year is a leap year.

tag.name: return
tag.description: true, if year is leap year

docblock.description: Internal mktime function used by Zend_Date for handling 64bit timestamps.
docblock.long-description: Returns a formatted date for a given timestamp.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL true = other arguments are for UTC time, false = arguments are for local time/date

docblock.description: Returns the day of week for a Gregorian calendar date.
docblock.long-description: 0 = sunday, 6 = saturday

docblock.description: Internal getDateParts function for handling 64bit timestamps, similar to: http://www.php.net/getdate
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of date parts for $timestamp, relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC.
$fast specifies ALL date parts should be returned (slower) Default is false, and excludes $dayofweek, weekday, month and timestamp from parts returned.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL defaults to fast (false), resulting in fewer date parts

docblock.description: Internal getWeekNumber function for handling 64bit timestamps
docblock.long-description: Returns the ISO 8601 week number of a given date

docblock.description: Internal _range function Sets the value $a to be in the range of [0, $b]
Calculates the sunrise or sunset based on a location
Sets a new timezone for calculation of $this object's gmt offset.
docblock.long-description: For a list of supported timezones look here: http://php.net/timezones If no timezone can be detected or the given timezone is wrong UTC will be set.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL timezone for date calculation; defaults to date_default_timezone_get()

docblock.long-description: The timezone is initially set when the object is instantiated.

docblock.description: Return the offset to GMT of $this object's timezone.
docblock.long-description: The offset to GMT is initially set when the object is instantiated using the currently, in effect, default timezone for PHP functions.

tag.name: return
tag.description: seconds difference between GMT timezone and timezone when object was instantiated

docblock.description: Internal method to check if the given cache supports tags

docblock.description: Set this object to have a new UNIX timestamp.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL timestamp; defaults to local time using time()

docblock.description: Returns this object's UNIX timestamp A timestamp greater then the integer range will be returned as string This function does not return the timestamp as object. Use copy() instead.

docblock.long-description: Returns time(). This method exists to allow unit tests to work-around methods that might otherwise be hard-coded to use time(). For example, this makes it possible to test isYesterday() in Date.php.

docblock.description: Internal mktime function used by Zend_Date.
docblock.long-description:
The timestamp returned by mktime() can exceed the precision of traditional UNIX timestamps, by allowing PHP to auto-convert to using a float value.
Returns a timestamp relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC. DST (Summer/Winter) is depriciated since php 5.1.0. Year has to be 4 digits otherwise it would be recognised as year 70 AD instead of 1970 AD as expected !!

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL true = other arguments are for UTC time, false = arguments are for local time/date

tag.name: return
tag.description: timestamp (number of seconds elapsed relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC)

docblock.description: Returns true, if given $year is a leap year.

tag.name: return
tag.description: true, if year is leap year

docblock.description: Internal mktime function used by Zend_Date for handling 64bit timestamps.
docblock.long-description: Returns a formatted date for a given timestamp.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL true = other arguments are for UTC time, false = arguments are for local time/date

docblock.description: Returns the day of week for a Gregorian calendar date.
docblock.long-description: 0 = sunday, 6 = saturday

docblock.description: Internal getDateParts function for handling 64bit timestamps, similar to: http://www.php.net/getdate
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of date parts for $timestamp, relative to 1970/01/01 00:00:00 GMT/UTC.
$fast specifies ALL date parts should be returned (slower) Default is false, and excludes $dayofweek, weekday, month and timestamp from parts returned.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL defaults to fast (false), resulting in fewer date parts

docblock.description: Internal getWeekNumber function for handling 64bit timestamps
docblock.long-description: Returns the ISO 8601 week number of a given date

docblock.description: Internal _range function Sets the value $a to be in the range of [0, $b]
Calculates the sunrise or sunset based on a location
Sets a new timezone for calculation of $this object's gmt offset.
docblock.long-description: For a list of supported timezones look here: http://php.net/timezones If no timezone can be detected or the given timezone is wrong UTC will be set.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL timezone for date calculation; defaults to date_default_timezone_get()

docblock.long-description: The timezone is initially set when the object is instantiated.

docblock.description: Return the offset to GMT of $this object's timezone.
docblock.long-description: The offset to GMT is initially set when the object is instantiated using the currently, in effect, default timezone for PHP functions.

tag.name: return
tag.description: seconds difference between GMT timezone and timezone when object was instantiated

docblock.long-description:
AMF 3 represents smaller integers with fewer bytes using the most significant bit of each byte. The worst case uses 32-bits to represent a 29-bit number, which is what we would have done with no compression. - 0x00000000 - 0x0000007F : 0xxxxxxx - 0x00000080 - 0x00003FFF : 1xxxxxxx 0xxxxxxx - 0x00004000 - 0x001FFFFF : 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx 0xxxxxxx - 0x00200000 - 0x3FFFFFFF : 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx xxxxxxxx - 0x40000000 - 0xFFFFFFFF : throw range exception
0x04 -> integer type code, followed by up to 4 bytes of data.
Parsing integers on OSFlash for the AMF3 integer data format:

Strings can be sent as a reference to a previously occurring String by using an index to the implicit string reference table. Strings are encoding using UTF-8 - however the header may either describe a string literal or a string reference.
- string = 0x06 string-data - string-data = integer-data [ modified-utf-8 ] - modified-utf-8 = *OCTET

Data is the number of milliseconds elapsed since the epoch of midnight, 1st Jan 1970 in the UTC time zone. Local time zone information is not sent to flash.
- date = 0x08 integer-data [ number-data ]

docblock.description: Read amf array to PHP array
docblock.long-description: - array = 0x09 integer-data ( [ 1OCTET *amf3-data ] | [OCTET *amf3-data 1] | [ OCTET *amf-data ] )

docblock.description: An AMF Message contains information about the actual individual transaction that is to be performed. It specifies the remote operation that is to be performed; a local (client) operation to be invoked upon success; and, the data to be used in the operation.
docblock.long-description: <p/> This Message structure defines how a local client would invoke a method/operation on a remote server. Additionally, the response from the Server is structured identically.

docblock.description: A string describing which operation, function, or method is to be remotley invoked.

Universal Resource Identifier that uniquely targets the originator's Object that should receive the server's response. The server will use this path specification to target the "OnResult()" or "onStatus()" handlers within the client. For Flash, it specifies an ActionScript Object path only. The NetResponse object pointed to by the Response Uri contains the connection state information. Passing/specifying this provides a convenient mechanism for the client/server to share access to an object that is managing the state of the shared connection.
docblock.long-description: Since the server will use this field in the event of an error, this field is required even if a successful server request would not be expected to return a value to the client.

docblock.description: Contains the actual data associated with the operation. It contains the client's parameter data that is passed to the server's operation/method.
docblock.long-description:
When serializing a root level data type or a parameter list array, no name field is included. That is, the data is anonomously represented as "Type Marker"/"Value" pairs. When serializing member data, the data is represented as a series of "Name"/"Type"/"Value" combinations.
For server generated responses, it may contain any ActionScript data/objects that the server was expected to provide.

Note: THESE VALUES MUST BE THE SAME ON CLIENT AND SERVER

docblock.description: This operation is used to subscribe to a remote destination.
This operation is used to unsubscribe from a remote destination.
This operation is used to poll a remote destination for pending, undelivered messages.
This operation is used by a remote destination to sync missed or cached messages back to a client as a result of a client issued poll command.
This operation is used to test connectivity over the current channel to the remote endpoint.
This operation is used to request a list of failover endpoint URIs for the remote destination based on cluster membership.
This operation is used to send credentials to the endpoint so that the user can be logged in over the current channel.
docblock.long-description: The credentials need to be Base64 encoded and stored in the body of the message.

docblock.description: This operation is used to log the user out of the current channel, and will invalidate the server session if the channel is HTTP based.
This operation is used to indicate that the client's subscription to a remote destination has been invalidated.
This operation is used by the MultiTopicConsumer to subscribe/unsubscribe from multiple subtopics/selectors in the same message.
This operation is used to indicate that a channel has disconnected
This is the default operation for new CommandMessage instances.

regenerateId() - Regenerate the session id. Best practice is to call this after session is started. If called prior to session starting, session id will be regenerated at start time.

rememberMe() - Write a persistent cookie that expires after a number of seconds in the future. If no number of seconds is specified, then this defaults to self::$_rememberMeSeconds. Due to clock errors on end users' systems, large values are recommended to avoid undesirable expiration of session cookies.

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL specifies TTL for cookie in seconds from present time

docblock.description: forgetMe() - Write a volatile session cookie, removing any persistent cookie that may have existed. The session would end upon, for example, termination of a web browser program.
rememberUntil() - This method does the work of changing the state of the session cookie and making sure that it gets resent to the browser via regenerateId()
sessionExists() - whether or not a session exists for the current request
Whether or not session has been destroyed via session_destroy()

tag.name: param
tag.description: OPTIONAL Either user supplied options, or flag indicating if start initiated automatically

docblock.description: Perform a hash-bits check on the session ID
_processGlobalMetadata() - this method initizes the sessions GLOBAL metadata, mostly global data expiration calculations.
isStarted() - convenience method to determine if the session is already started.
isRegenerated() - convenience method to determine if session_regenerate_id() has been called during this request by Zend_Session.
getId() - get the current session id
setId() - set an id to a user specified id
registerValidator() - register a validator that will attempt to validate this session for every future request
stop() - Disable write access. Optionally disable read (not implemented).
writeClose() - Shutdown the sesssion, close writing and detach $_SESSION from the back-end storage mechanism.
docblock.long-description: This will complete the internal data transformation on this request.

docblock.description: expireSessionCookie() - Sends an expired session id cookie, causing the client to delete the session cookie
_processValidator() - internal function that is called in the existence of VALID metadata
namespaceIsset() - check to see if a namespace is set
namespaceUnset() - unset a namespace or a variable within a namespace
namespaceGet() - get all variables in a namespace Deprecated: Use getIterator() in Zend_Session_Namespace.
getIterator() - return an iteratable object for use in foreach and the like, this completes the IteratorAggregate interface
isWritable() - returns a boolean indicating if namespaces can write (use setters)
isReadable() - returns a boolean indicating if namespaces can write (use setters)

namespaceUnset() - unset a namespace or a variable within a namespace

docblock.description: Set the path to the credentials file
Returns the path to the credentials file

docblock.long-description:
Only the first matching username/realm combination in the file is returned. If the file contains credentials for Digest authentication, the returned string is the password hash, or h(a1) from RFC 2617. The returned string is the plain-text password for Basic authentication.
The expected format of the file is: username:realm:sharedSecret
That is, each line consists of the user's username, the applicable authentication realm, and the password or hash, each delimited by colons.

docblock.description: Reference to the HTTP Request object
Reference to the HTTP Response object
Object that looks up user credentials for the Basic scheme
Object that looks up user credentials for the Digest scheme
List of authentication schemes supported by this class
List of schemes this class will accept from the client
Space-delimited list of protected domains for Digest Auth
Whether to send the opaque value in the header. True by default
List of the supported digest algorithms. I want to support both MD5 and MD5-sess, but MD5-sess won't make it into the first version.
The actual algorithm to use. Defaults to MD5
List of supported qop options. My intetion is to support both 'auth' and 'auth-int', but 'auth-int' won't make it into the first version.
Whether or not to do Proxy Authentication instead of origin server authentication (send 407's instead of 401's). Off by default.
Flag indicating the client is IE and didn't bother to return the opaque string

tag.name: param
tag.description: Configuration settings: 'accept_schemes' => 'basic'|'digest'|'basic digest' 'realm' => 'digest_domains' => Space-delimited list of URIs 'nonce_timeout' => 'use_opaque' => Whether to send the opaque value in the header 'alogrithm' => See $_supportedAlgos. Default: MD5 'proxy_auth' => Whether to do authentication as a Proxy

docblock.long-description: Sets a 401 or 407 Unauthorized response code, and creates the appropriate Authenticate header(s) to prompt for credentials.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Always returns a non-identity Auth result

docblock.long-description: Generates a Proxy- or WWW-Authenticate header value in the Basic authentication scheme.
Generates a Proxy- or WWW-Authenticate header value in the Digest authentication scheme.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Valid auth result only on successful auth

docblock.long-description: The opaque string can be anything; the client must return it exactly as it was sent. It may be useful to store data in this string in some applications. Ideally, a new value for this would be generated each time a WWW-Authenticate header is sent (in order to reduce predictability), but we would have to be able to create the same exact value across at least two separate requests from the same client.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Data elements from header, or false if any part of the header is invalid

docblock.description: Securely compare two strings for equality while avoided C level memcmp() optimisations capable of leaking timing information useful to an attacker attempting to iteratively guess the unknown string (e.g. password) being compared against.

docblock.description: $_identityColumn - the column to use as the identity
$_credentialColumns - columns to be used as the credentials
$_credentialTreatment - Treatment applied to the credential, such as MD5() or PASSWORD()
$_ambiguityIdentity - Flag to indicate same Identity can be used with different credentials. Default is FALSE and need to be set to true to allow ambiguity usage.
_setDbAdapter() - set the database adapter to be used for quering
setTableName() - set the table name to be used in the select query
setIdentityColumn() - set the column name to be used as the identity column
setCredentialColumn() - set the column name to be used as the credential column
setCredentialTreatment() - allows the developer to pass a parameterized string that is used to transform or treat the input credential data.
docblock.long-description:
In many cases, passwords and other sensitive data are encrypted, hashed, encoded, obscured, or otherwise treated through some function or algorithm. By specifying a parameterized treatment string with this method, a developer may apply arbitrary SQL upon input credential data.
Examples:
'PASSWORD(?)' 'MD5(?)'

docblock.description: setIdentity() - set the value to be used as the identity
setCredential() - set the credential value to be used, optionally can specify a treatment to be used, should be supplied in parameterized form, such as 'MD5(?)' or 'PASSWORD(?)'
setAmbiguityIdentity() - sets a flag for usage of identical identities with unique credentials. It accepts integers (0, 1) or boolean (true, false) parameters. Default is false.
getAmbiguityIdentity() - returns TRUE for usage of multiple identical identies with different credentials, FALSE if not used.
getDbSelect() - Return the preauthentication Db Select object for userland select query modification
getResultRowObject() - Returns the result row as a stdClass object

authenticate() - defined by Zend_Auth_Adapter_Interface. This method is called to attempt an authentication. Previous to this call, this adapter would have already been configured with all necessary information to successfully connect to a database table and attempt to find a record matching the provided identity.
